children: Pulmonary function testing can include spirometry, response to bronchodilators, bronchial challenge testing, lung volume testing, and measurement of D
. These findings are compared with age, sex, height, and race-adjusted population norms and are expressed as a percentage of the predicted value

. The use of race as a variable in establishing predicted values is inappropriate, and alternate means of describing norms have been proposed. The 2005 American Thoracic Society guidelines define the lower limit of normal as below the fifth percentile of the predicted value; some laboratories use this as their cutoff, and typically this coincides with 80% of the predicted value.
In general, pulmonary function test results below 80% of predicted indicate pulmonary impairment.
Spirometry measures the maximal volume and flow of air during a best-effort forced exhalation; reported values include FEV

/FVC ratio. Spirometry correlates with home peak expiratory flow meter measurements but is more reliable, provides more data, and is used in diagnosis and management of airways disease. Although spirometry is easily performed in the outpatient setting, technical test validation and patient factors, including poor effort, coughing, and failure to exhale for a minimum of 6 seconds, may result in suboptimal test performance and misinterpretation. If spirometry is unable to be performed, fractional exhaled nitric oxide measurement may help in the diagnosis of asthma (see following section).

Bronchial challenge testing is used to identify bronchial hyperresponsiveness. This is particularly helpful in patients whose symptoms suggest asthma but for whom other pulmonary function test results are normal. Patients inhale increasing doses of a substance known to induce bronchospasm, such as methacholine or histamine, in a stepwise fashion. This is followed by repeated measurement of FEV
; the test is considered positive if FEV

falls by 20% or more from the baseline value. Bronchial challenge testing has a high negative predictive value for ruling out asthma. However, a positive test can be caused by other conditions, including COPD, smoking, upper respiratory infections, allergic rhinitis, bronchiectasis, and cystic fibrosis.
Bronchial challenge testing is a helpful diagnostic tool to use for patients whose symptoms suggest asthma but for whom other pulmonary function test results are normal.

Lung volumes can be measured by body plethysmography of nitrogen diffusion. Measures include total lung capacity (TLC), vital capacity, functional residual capacity, expiratory reserve volume, and residual volume. D
measurement estimates the amount of gas transfer through the alveolar-capillary unit and is proportional to the surface area of functional lung. D
is measured by inhalation of a gas mixture containing carbon monoxide and helium; the resulting value is corrected for hemoglobin level.
The purpose of pulmonary function testing interpretation is to classify abnormal results as obstructive, restrictive, or mixed obstructive/restrictive and to assess the severity of impairment
/FVC ratio is consistent with obstruction, and the severity of obstruction is determined according to the measured FEV
as a percentage of the predicted value (see
. The American Thoracic Society and the European Respiratory Society define a reduced FEV
/FVC ratio as being below the lower limit of normal, whereas the Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease defines it as below 0.70. An increase from baseline in FEV

, FVC, or both of at least 12% and at least 200 mL indicates a positive bronchodilator response (reversibility). TLC is normal or even increased in pure obstructive disease. Elevation of TLC and residual volume (120% or greater of predicted) can be observed in obstruction and generally indicates hyperinflation and air trapping, a common pattern in severe COPD and asthma.
or FVC is reduced and the FEV

/FVC ratio is 0.70 or greater, then the pattern may be interpreted as restrictive, but measurement of TLC is needed to confirm this. If TLC is less than 80% of predicted (or the lower limit of normal), a restrictive pattern is present.
Some patients present with coexisting obstructive and restrictive pulmonary disorders, such as COPD and interstitial lung disease. In these cases, a low FEV
/FVC ratio (obstructive) and a low TLC (restrictive) are both present.

is reduced in conditions in which functioning alveolar-capillary units are destroyed (COPD), infiltrated (interstitial lung diseases), or removed (lung resection), and in which their function is compromised (pulmonary parenchymal and vascular disorders). Conditions that increase pulmonary capillary blood volume, such as pulmonary alveolar hemorrhage, left-to-right shunt, or asthma, can cause an elevation in D

The flow-volume loop is a graphic representation of maximally forced inspiratory and expiratory flow (on the Y-axis) against volume (on the X-axis). The shape of the spirometric flow-volume loop is also useful in differentiating obstructive from restrictive patterns
The purpose of pulmonary function testing interpretation is to classify abnormal results as either obstructive or restrictive and to assess the severity of impairment.
/FVC ratio is the primary measurement that defines obstructive disease, and total lung capacity is the primary measurement used to confirm restrictive disease.

The 6-minute walk test provides a valid and reliable measurement of exercise capacity in patients with lung disease. Patients walk at their own pace along a course for 6 minutes, and the total distance walked is recorded. Lower 6-minute walk test distances correlate with increased mortality in several lung diseases, including COPD, interstitial lung disease, and pulmonary arterial hypertension. Serial 6-minute walk testing may be used to assess response to therapy in patients with chronic respiratory disorders, especially pulmonary arterial hypertension.

Oximeters work by calculating the difference between absorption of infrared light by oxygenated and deoxygenated blood. A normal hemoglobin saturation measured by pulse oximetry is 95% to 100%, and values below 90% indicate hypoxemia. Substances in the blood that absorb infrared light may cause erroneous readings, including carboxyhemoglobin (present in carbon monoxide poisoning), methemoglobin (caused by nitrates), methylene blue, and some topical anesthetics. More commonly, patient factors such as cool extremities, poor circulation, nail polish, and motion artifact result in erroneous readings. In these cases, alternative methods of measuring oxygenation, such as arterial blood gas analysis, are needed.

Measurement of the fraction of nitric oxide in an exhaled breath sample (FeNO) provides a noninvasive way to quantify eosinophilic airway inflammation and serves as a complementary tool in the management of lung diseases—asthma in particular. Elevated FeNO levels correlate modestly with blood and sputum eosinophilia. More than half of patients with asthma have eosinophilic (type 2) airway inflammation, and FeNO levels may help predict glucocorticoid responsiveness in these patients as well as monitor their response to and adherence to anti-inflammatory therapy. The American Thoracic Society guidelines suggest that FeNO levels above 50 ppb indicate glucocorticoid-sensitive airway inflammation. Patients with levels below 25 ppb are less likely to have eosinophilic inflammation and glucocorticoid responsiveness. Fractional exhaled nitric oxide testing is recommended as an adjunct in asthma evaluation for those aged 5 years and older. A specific but conditional recommendation for the use of nitric oxide testing applies when a patient is being considered for asthma therapy. Other possible scenarios for FeNO measurement include when the diagnosis of asthma is uncertain after standard evaluation or when spirometry cannot be performed, or in persistent allergic asthma and uncertainty in choosing, monitoring, or adjusting medications.
provides information on various imaging modalities and their indications.

Conventional chest radiographs are indicated as the initial imaging procedure for most patients with significant respiratory symptoms. Posteroanterior and lateral views should be obtained. The advantages are the availability of testing and the low dose of radiation exposure for the patient. The limitations include the need to take a deep inspiration, breath holding, image resolution, and the two-dimensional images produced.

CT of the thorax allows detailed, high-resolution imaging of the lungs and options for both static and dynamic imaging techniques. Helical scanners allow rapid scanning but may require patients to hold their breath at full inspiration for 30 seconds or more. Reconstruction can include sagittal and coronal images, which result in three-dimensional representation of the extent and distribution of disease. More specialized techniques reformat the data to highlight specific structures; they include maximum intensity projection, which focuses on the vasculature, and minimum intensity projection, which focuses on the airways. Additional variables in CT imaging include slice thickness and interval. Contrast enhancement may be used to augment the value of imaging on the basis of the underlying disease.

The choice of examination depends on the clinical context and information sought. Noncontrast CT is usually preferred because contrast makes assessing the lung parenchyma more difficult. For most patients, routine (slice thickness of 2 or 2.5 mm) noncontrast CT provides the needed information. For patients suspected of having interstitial lung disease, a high-resolution (slice thickness of 1 mm) study should be ordered. Additional expiratory views can evaluate for air trapping and further inform the diagnosis of small airways disease. However, because the slice interval (the distance between individual slices) with high-resolution CT is larger than with conventional CT, this technique “skips” interval sections of the lung and should not be used to evaluate lung nodules. Use of intravenous contrast dye helps delineate mediastinal structures and is particularly useful in patients with suspected lymphadenopathy or vascular pathology. CT angiography is used for detection of pulmonary embolism and uses a rapid, timed bolus of intravenous contrast.

CT scanning exposes the patient to a much higher dose of radiation than traditional chest radiographs, and CT is currently the primary source of imaging radiation exposure for patients. Low-dose CT scanning is now the recommended choice for lung cancer screening in the United States (see

High-resolution CT techniques are preferred for evaluation of interstitial lung disease; conventional noncontrast CT is used to evaluate lung nodules and most other lung disease; and CT angiography is used for detection of pulmonary embolism.

title.__html: Ultrasonography of the Lung and Diaphragm

children: Ultrasonography of the Lung and Diaphragm

Point-of-care thoracic ultrasonography provides a noninvasive means of rapidly assessing the lungs, pleura, and diaphragm. It is particularly helpful for critically ill patients for whom the use of other imaging techniques requiring transport may pose undue risk or delay diagnosis. Thoracic ultrasonography detects the presence and volume of pleural effusions more accurately than chest radiography; it can also identify characteristics that suggest an effusion and difficulty or risks with draining the effusion. In addition, performing pleural drainage procedures such as thoracentesis or tube thoracostomy with ultrasound guidance reduces risks for complications, including pneumothorax. Thoracic ultrasonography assesses diaphragm function more accurately than fluoroscopy. Ultrasonography of the lung parenchyma can identify consolidation, whereas demonstration of movement of the visceral pleura against the parietal pleura (lung sliding sign [

]) excludes a pneumothorax at the area scanned. Obesity and significant edema or musculature can degrade image quality and limit ultrasound usefulness, whereas complex or high-density pleural collections (empyema, hemothorax) may be too echogenic for accurate detection or identification of adjacent tissue structures.

PET uses the radionuclide 18-fluoro-2-deoxyglucose, which accumulates within highly metabolically active cells such as cancer cells and can be visualized as discrete areas of uptake. Integrated PET/CT allows improved localization of the metabolic activity. PET scans are widely used to evaluate the likelihood of malignancy in lung nodules, to stage known thoracic tumors, and to evaluate for metastatic disease from other nonthoracic malignancies. False-positive PET scans can occur in other hypermetabolic conditions in which cells accumulate fluorodeoxyglucose, such as infection or inflammation. False negatives can occur when tumors have low rates of metabolic activity, such as carcinoid, adenocarcinoma in situ, and rarely, metastatic kidney, prostate, or testicular cancer. PET is not useful for the determination of malignant potential in lung nodules less than 8 mm in size.

tool for patients with lung disorders. It is used for the diagnosis of localized and diffuse pulmonary diseases and is important in the diagnostic evaluation of pulmonary infections, particularly in the immunocompromised host, as well as for various therapeutic uses. Endobronchial ultrasonography is the initial procedure of choice for obtaining tissue from mediastinal and hilar lymph nodes in the diagnosis and staging of patients with known or suspected thoracic malignancy.
Endobronchial ultrasonography is the initial procedure of choice for obtaining tissue from mediastinal and hilar lymph nodes in the staging of patients with known or suspected thoracic malignancy.

children: Initial imaging for most pulmonary patients
Evaluate abnormality seen on chest radiograph
Visualize small lesions not seen on chest radiograph
Risks with use of intravenous contrast (kidney toxicity, anaphylaxis)
Image acquisition is operator and patient dependent
Allows correlation of anatomy with physiologic activity
Visualization of the tracheobronchial tree to the level of segmental airways
Samples from small bronchi and alveoli
Cell counts in diagnosis of parenchymal lung disease
Brushings of the endobronchial mucosa for cells
Biopsy of the lung parenchyma or lung nodules/masses using small forceps; often aided by guidance technology, including fluoroscopy, electromagnetic navigation, and radial ultrasonography
Aspiration of a lymph node or mass adjacent to the airway
Use of an ultrasound probe at the distal end of the bronchoscope to guide transbronchial needle aspiration
Images from a recent CT are “linked” with the bronchoscope; an electromagnetic guidance system at the bronchoscope creates a map of the airways and guides the physician to the area of interest
Radiofrequency energy ablation of proximal airway smooth muscle
Bronchoscopic placement of silicon and metal prostheses to expand and support the airways
